aws::graph::propositions: # Engine Bearing and Crankshaft Examination Findings
The Number 1 main bearing displayed normal wear and a few score marks consistent with hard-particle-passage.
The Number 2 main bearing displayed normal wear and a few score marks consistent with hard-particle-passage.
There was no sign of lock tab movement on the Number 1 main bearing.
There was no sign of lock slot elongation on the Number 1 main bearing.
There was no sign of lock tab movement on the Number 2 main bearing.
There was no sign of lock slot elongation on the Number 2 main bearing.
The Number 3 main bearing displayed wear and scoring that removed the babbit layer.
The Number 3 main bearing displayed the copper underlay.
There was no sign of lock tab movement on the Number 3 main bearing.
There was no sign of lock slot elongation on the Number 3 main bearing.
The Number 4 main bearing was discolored black.
The Number 4 main bearing was heavily worn.
The Number 4 main bearing was displaced in the saddle.
The Number 4 main bearing split line did not match up with the case half split line.
There was no evidence of lateral lock slot elongation on the Number 4 main bearing.
The oil feed to the backside of the Number 4 bearing was unobstructed.
The Number 5 main bearing was discolored black.
The Number 5 main bearing was heavily worn.
The Number 5 main bearing was displaced in the saddle.
The Number 5 main bearing split line did not match up with the case half split line.
There was no evidence of lateral lock slot elongation on the Number 5 main bearing.
The oil feed to the backside of the Number 5 bearing was obstructed by displaced saddle material.
The crankshaft remained intact.
The crankshaft displayed thermal distress at the Number 1 connecting rod journal.
The crankshaft displayed thermal distress at the Number 2 connecting rod journal.
The crankshaft displayed thermal distress at the Number 6 connecting rod journal.
The Number 6 connecting rod journal was mechanically damaged.
The oil feed hole on the Number 6 connecting rod journal was no longer visible due to displaced material.
The crankshaft's Number 4 main bearing journal displayed black thermal discoloration.
The crankshaft's Number 5 main bearing journal displayed black thermal discoloration.
The crankshaft's Number 5 bearing journal displayed material displacement.
All of the crankshaft oil tubes were clear of debris with the exception of the Number 6 connecting rod journal.

text:
# Transcription of Page 4 of 8 (WPR15LA032)

## The Number 1 and 2 Main Bearings
- Displayed normal wear and a few score marks consistent with hard-particle-passage
- There was no sign of lock tab movement or lock slot elongation

## The Number 3 Main Bearing
- Displayed wear and scoring that removed the babbit layer and displayed the copper underlay
- There was no sign of lock tab movement or lock slot elongation

## The Number 4 Main Bearing
- Was discolored black, heavily worn, and displaced in the saddle such that the bearing split line did not match up with the case half split line
- There was no evidence of lateral lock slot elongation
- The oil feed to the backside of the number 4 bearing was unobstructed

## The Number 5 Main Bearing
- Was discolored black, heavily worn, and displaced in the saddle such that the bearing split line did not match up with the case half split line
- There was no evidence of lateral lock slot elongation
- The oil feed to the backside of the number 5 bearing was obstructed by displaced saddle material

## The Crankshaft
- Remained intact but displayed thermal distress at the number 1, number 2, and the number 6 connecting rod journals
- The number 6 connecting rod journal was also mechanically damaged and the oil feed hole was no longer visible due to the displaced material
- The crankshaft's number 4 and number 5 main bearing journals displayed black thermal discoloration, along with material displacement at the number 5 bearing journal
- All of the crankshaft oil tubes were clear of debris with the exception of the number 6 connecting rod journal,
